Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: Contributions of Kansas rangeland burning to ambient O<sub>3</sub>: Analysis of data from 2001 to 2016.

AbstractText: Prescribed range/pasture burning is a common practice in Kansas to enhance the nutritional value of native grasses and control invading weeds, trees, and brush. A major concern associated with the burning is the contribution of smoke to elevated ground level ambient ozone (O<sub>3</sub>). The objective of this study is to estimate contributions of Kansas rangeland burning to ambient O<sub>3</sub> mixing ratios through regression analysis (1) between observed O<sub>3</sub> data and available satellite burn activity data from 2001 to 2016; and (2) between observed O<sub>3</sub> data and the smoke contributions to PM<sub>2.5</sub> which were resolved from receptor modeling. Positive correlations were observed between ambient O<sub>3</sub> levels and the acres burned each year estimated from satellite imagery. When burned acres in April were larger than or equal to 1.9 million, O<sub>3</sub>>70ppb occurred at least at one of the ten monitoring sites in Kansas. Statistical regression models of daily maximum 8-hour O<sub>3</sub> mixing ratios were developed at each of the ten monitoring sites using meteorological predictors. The O<sub>3</sub> model residuals that were not explained by the meteorological effect models were affected by PM<sub>2.5</sub> contributors including sulfate/industrial sources and emissions that generated secondary organic particles, such as rangeland burning, which were derived from receptor modeling. The average O<sub>3</sub> model residual on the high O<sub>3</sub> days in April was 21±9ppb, which was likely associated with smoke emissions from burning. Research will continue to obtain daily satellite burn activity data and to correlate burn data with daily O<sub>3</sub> data, so that modeling of O<sub>3</sub> levels can be improved under influences of daily burn activities. Less frequency of high O<sub>3</sub> days was observed in April since 2011, which may be partly due to implementation of the Flint Hills Smoke Management Plan which promoted better timing of burns.
